metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Apply the concepts of force due to gravity and normal force including in relation to satellites in orbit where the orbits are assumed to be uniform and circular

gravitational_force_centripetal.name: Gravity as Centripetal Force
gravitational_force_centripetal.correct: For satellites in circular orbit, gravitational force provides the centripetal force. Gravity is the ONLY force acting on the satellite.

tension.error: Satellites are not connected by strings or cables.
tension.fix: There is no physical connection between satellite and planet. Gravity acts at a distance through the gravitational field.
tension.action: List all forces acting on a satellite. There should only be one: gravity.

normal force.error: Normal force requires contact with a surface. Satellites are not touching anything.
normal force.fix: In orbit, there is no surface to push against. The satellite is in free fall.
normal force.action: Normal force only exists when objects are in contact. Satellites orbit in empty space.

friction.fix: In the vacuum of space, there are no air molecules to create friction. Only gravity acts.
friction.action: Consider what forces could act through empty space. Only field forces like gravity work this way.

persistent.gap: You are adding forces that do not exist for orbiting satellites.
persistent.action: Draw a free body diagram of a satellite. If you draw more than one force arrow (gravity), something is wrong.

centripetal_direction.name: Direction of Centripetal Force
centripetal_direction.correct: Centripetal force always points radially INWARD, toward the centre of the circular path. For satellites, this is toward the planet's centre.

radially outward.error: This describes centrifugal force, which is a fictitious force in a rotating reference frame, not a real force.
radially outward.fix: Centripetal means 'centre-seeking'. The force pulls TOWARD the centre, not away from it.
radially outward.action: Think about a ball on a string. The string pulls the ball toward your hand (the centre), not away.

tangential.error: Tangential is the direction of velocity, not force, in circular motion.
tangential.fix: Force is perpendicular to velocity in circular motion. Force points inward, velocity points along the circle.
tangential.action: Draw the velocity vector (tangent to circle) and force vector (toward centre). They should be at 90 degrees.

in the direction of motion.error: That would cause the satellite to speed up, not turn.
in the direction of motion.fix: Force parallel to velocity changes speed. Force perpendicular to velocity changes direction.
in the direction of motion.action: What happens when you push something in the direction it is already moving? It speeds up, not turns.

persistent.gap: You are confusing force direction with velocity direction in circular motion.
persistent.action: Memorise: velocity is tangent to the circle, centripetal force points toward the centre. Always perpendicular.

velocity_direction.name: Satellite Velocity Direction
velocity_direction.correct: A satellite's velocity vector is always tangent to its circular orbital path, perpendicular to the gravitational force.

toward the planet.error: That would describe the direction of acceleration, not velocity.
toward the planet.fix: If velocity were toward the planet, the satellite would crash. Velocity is along the orbit path.
toward the planet.action: Velocity shows where the object is GOING. Satellites go around the planet, not into it.

away from the planet.error: That would mean the satellite is moving outward, escaping orbit.
away from the planet.fix: In stable orbit, velocity is tangent to the circular path, neither toward nor away.
away from the planet.action: Draw the circular orbit. Velocity at any point is the tangent line to the circle.

parallel to gravitational force.error: Velocity is perpendicular to gravitational force in circular orbit.
parallel to gravitational force.fix: For uniform circular motion, velocity must be perpendicular to centripetal force.
parallel to gravitational force.action: If velocity and force were parallel, the satellite would either speed up or slow down, not orbit.

persistent.gap: You are confusing velocity direction with force or acceleration direction.
persistent.action: Draw a circle. Mark a point. Velocity is tangent to the circle at that point. Force points to the centre.

orbital_force_balance.name: Force Balance in Orbit
orbital_force_balance.correct: In stable circular orbit, gravity IS the net force. There is no force 'balance' - gravity provides the centripetal acceleration for circular motion.

gravity equals centrifugal force.error: Centrifugal force is not a real force. It is a fictitious force that appears only in rotating reference frames.
gravity equals centrifugal force.fix: From an inertial reference frame, only gravity acts. The satellite is constantly accelerating inward.
gravity equals centrifugal force.action: Never use centrifugal force in physics problems unless specifically asked to analyse from a rotating frame.

forces are balanced.error: If forces were balanced (Fnet = 0), there would be no acceleration and no circular motion.
forces are balanced.fix: Circular motion requires continuous acceleration toward the centre. Fnet is not zero.
forces are balanced.action: Apply Newton's second law: a = Fnet/m. If a exists (circular motion), Fnet cannot be zero.

no forces act.error: Gravity definitely acts. The satellite experiences continuous gravitational force.
no forces act.fix: At ISS altitude (400 km), g is still about 90% of surface value. Gravity is very much present.
no forces act.action: Calculate g at ISS altitude using g = GM/r². It is approximately 8.7 m/s², not zero.

persistent.gap: You do not understand that circular motion requires a net inward force.
persistent.action: Review: acceleration requires net force. Circular motion has centripetal acceleration, so there must be net centripetal force.

normal_force_definition.name: Normal Force Definition
normal_force_definition.correct: Normal force is a contact force that acts perpendicular to a surface. It exists only when objects are physically touching a surface.

acts on all objects.error: Normal force only exists when there is physical contact with a surface.
acts on all objects.fix: Objects in free fall or orbit experience no normal force because they are not touching any surface.
acts on all objects.action: Ask: is the object touching a surface? If no, then normal force is zero.

same as gravity.error: Normal force and gravity are different forces that may or may not be equal.
same as gravity.fix: Normal force equals gravity only when stationary on a horizontal surface with no other vertical forces.
same as gravity.action: In an accelerating elevator, FN differs from Fg. On a slope, FN = Fg cos θ, not Fg.

always opposes gravity.error: Normal force is perpendicular to the contact surface, which is not always opposite to gravity.
always opposes gravity.fix: On a slope, normal force is perpendicular to the slope, not vertical. It does not fully oppose gravity.
always opposes gravity.action: Draw FN and Fg for an object on a ramp. They are not opposite.

persistent.gap: You have a fundamental misunderstanding of what normal force is and when it exists.
persistent.action: Normal force = surface pushes back. No surface contact = no normal force. Period.

apparent_weight.name: Apparent Weight
apparent_weight.correct: Apparent weight is what you 'feel' - it equals the normal force acting on you. We do not directly feel gravity; we feel surfaces pushing on us.

always equals mg.error: Apparent weight only equals mg when stationary with no vertical acceleration.
always equals mg.fix: In an accelerating system, apparent weight = m(g ± a). In orbit, apparent weight is zero.
always equals mg.action: Calculate apparent weight in an elevator accelerating upward: FN = m(g + a), not mg.

equals gravitational force.error: We feel normal force, not gravitational force. They are different quantities.
equals gravitational force.fix: Gravity pulls every part of you uniformly. Normal force pushes only on contact points.
equals gravitational force.action: In free fall, gravity acts but apparent weight is zero because there is no surface contact.

is the same everywhere.error: Apparent weight depends on acceleration and surface contact, which vary.
is the same everywhere.fix: Apparent weight changes in elevators, on roller coasters, and in orbit.
is the same everywhere.action: Think about how you feel heavier when an elevator accelerates upward.

persistent.gap: You are confusing gravitational force with the sensation of weight.
persistent.action: Memorise: We feel FN, not Fg. Apparent weight = normal force = what scales measure.

weightlessness_cause.name: Cause of Apparent Weightlessness
weightlessness_cause.correct: Astronauts feel weightless because they are in free fall. Both the astronaut and spacecraft accelerate at the same rate, so there is no normal force between them.

no gravity in space.error: Gravity is very much present at orbital altitudes. At ISS height, g is about 8.7 m/s².
no gravity in space.fix: Weightlessness is not due to absence of gravity but due to free fall. The astronaut and station fall together.
no gravity in space.action: Calculate g at 400 km altitude. It is approximately 90% of surface gravity, not zero.

too far from Earth.error: Orbital altitudes are not far enough for gravity to be negligible.
too far from Earth.fix: ISS is only 400 km up. Earth's radius is 6400 km. That is not 'far' in gravitational terms.
too far from Earth.action: Compare 400 km to Earth's radius of 6400 km. The ISS is very close to Earth.

centrifugal force cancels gravity.error: Centrifugal force is fictitious. In an inertial frame, there is only gravity.
centrifugal force cancels gravity.fix: Weightlessness occurs because astronaut and station are both in free fall, accelerating equally.
centrifugal force cancels gravity.action: Avoid using centrifugal force explanations. Focus on free fall and equal acceleration.

persistent.gap: You think weightlessness means no gravity acts. This is a major misconception.
persistent.action: The ISS is falling around Earth. Astronauts are falling at the same rate. That is why they float.

free_fall_definition.name: Free Fall
free_fall_definition.correct: Free fall occurs when gravity is the ONLY force acting on an object. The object accelerates at g regardless of its mass.

falling without air resistance.error: Free fall is defined by gravity being the only force, not just the absence of air resistance.
falling without air resistance.fix: In orbit, satellites are in free fall even though they are moving sideways, not falling 'down'.
falling without air resistance.action: Free fall means Fnet = Fg. This can occur while orbiting, not just while dropping.

falling straight down.error: Free fall can occur in any direction, including sideways (orbital motion).
falling straight down.fix: Satellites in circular orbit are in free fall - they are falling around the planet continuously.
falling straight down.action: Newton's cannonball thought experiment: shoot fast enough and you fall around the Earth.

only occurs near Earth surface.error: Free fall occurs anywhere gravity is the only force, including deep space.
only occurs near Earth surface.fix: An astronaut floating in the ISS is in free fall, even though they are 400 km up.
only occurs near Earth surface.action: Free fall is about forces, not location. Gravity only = free fall, anywhere in the universe.

persistent.gap: You have a narrow definition of free fall limited to objects falling downward.
persistent.action: Redefine free fall: gravity is the ONLY force. This includes orbiting objects.

satellite_mass_independence.name: Mass Independence of Orbital Motion
satellite_mass_independence.correct: Satellite mass does not affect orbital speed or period. All satellites at the same altitude orbit at the same speed.

heavier satellites orbit faster.error: Orbital speed depends on orbital radius and central body mass, not satellite mass.
heavier satellites orbit faster.fix: From Fg = Fc: GMm/r² = mv²/r. The m cancels, giving v = √(GM/r).
heavier satellites orbit faster.action: Derive the orbital speed formula. Watch the satellite mass cancel out.

heavier satellites need more force.error: True, but they also have more inertia, so acceleration is the same.
heavier satellites need more force.fix: F = ma. More mass needs more force, but a = F/m stays constant for given altitude.
heavier satellites need more force.action: This is Galileo's insight: all objects fall at the same rate regardless of mass.

lighter satellites orbit at higher altit.error: Orbital altitude is independent of satellite mass.
lighter satellites orbit at higher altit.fix: The orbital radius depends on desired period or coverage, not mass.
lighter satellites orbit at higher altit.action: Satellites are placed at specific altitudes for mission requirements, not based on mass.

persistent.gap: You think satellite mass affects orbital motion. It does not.
persistent.action: Derive v = √(GM/r) from scratch. Note that satellite mass m cancels completely.

orbital_radius_measurement.name: Orbital Radius Measurement
orbital_radius_measurement.correct: Orbital radius is measured from the CENTRE of the planet, not its surface. Add planet radius to altitude above surface.

altitude above surface.error: Altitude and orbital radius are different quantities.
altitude above surface.fix: Orbital radius r = planet radius R + altitude h. Always measure from planet centre.
altitude above surface.action: ISS altitude is 400 km, but orbital radius is 6400 + 400 = 6800 km from Earth's centre.

distance from planet edge.error: Gravitational formulas use distance from the centre of mass, not the edge.
distance from planet edge.fix: The planet's mass acts as if concentrated at the centre. Radius is measured from there.
distance from planet edge.action: In g = GM/r², the r is from the centre. Surface r = planet radius.

half the orbital diameter.error: This would give the radius of the orbit, but measured incorrectly from the orbit, not the planet centre.
half the orbital diameter.fix: Orbital radius = distance from planet centre to satellite. Planet centre is at the orbit centre.
half the orbital diameter.action: The planet sits at the centre of the orbital circle. Radius goes from planet centre to satellite.

persistent.gap: You are measuring orbital radius from the wrong reference point.
persistent.action: Always add: r = Rplanet + altitude. Never use altitude alone in orbital formulas.

uniform_circular_motion.name: Uniform Circular Motion Model
uniform_circular_motion.correct: In uniform circular motion, speed is constant but velocity changes because direction changes continuously. Acceleration is centripetal.

constant velocity.error: Velocity includes direction. In circular motion, direction constantly changes, so velocity changes.
constant velocity.fix: Speed is constant (magnitude of velocity), but velocity vector rotates around the circle.
constant velocity.action: Draw velocity vectors at 4 points around a circle. Same length, different directions.

no acceleration.error: Changing direction requires acceleration, even if speed is constant.
no acceleration.fix: Centripetal acceleration = v²/r. It exists whenever an object moves in a circle.
no acceleration.action: Apply Newton's laws: force causes acceleration. Centripetal force causes centripetal acceleration.

acceleration in direction of motion.error: That would change speed, not direction.
acceleration in direction of motion.fix: Centripetal acceleration is perpendicular to velocity, toward the centre.
acceleration in direction of motion.action: Force perpendicular to motion changes direction. Force parallel to motion changes speed.

persistent.gap: You do not distinguish between speed (scalar) and velocity (vector).
persistent.action: Speed = magnitude only. Velocity = magnitude AND direction. Direction change = velocity change.

geostationary_orbit.name: Geostationary Orbit
geostationary_orbit.formula: T = 24 hours, equatorial, same rotation direction
geostationary_orbit.correct: A geostationary satellite has a 24-hour period, orbits above the equator, and moves in the same direction as Earth's rotation, staying above one point.

any orbit with 24 hour period.error: Period alone is not sufficient. The orbit must also be equatorial and prograde.
any orbit with 24 hour period.fix: A 24-hour polar orbit would not stay above one point - it needs to be above the equator.
any orbit with 24 hour period.action: Geostationary needs three conditions: T = 24 h, equatorial plane, same direction as Earth rotation.

stationary in space.error: The satellite moves at about 3 km/s. It appears stationary relative to Earth's surface.
stationary in space.fix: Geostationary means stationary relative to ground, not stationary in space.
stationary in space.action: Calculate geostationary orbital speed: about 3.07 km/s. Definitely moving.

at any altitude.error: Only one altitude gives a 24-hour period: about 35,786 km above Earth's surface.
at any altitude.fix: Period depends on altitude. T = 24 h requires a specific radius from Kepler's third law.
at any altitude.action: Calculate: 4π²r³ = GMT² with T = 86400 s gives r ≈ 42,000 km from Earth's centre.

persistent.gap: You do not understand all the requirements for geostationary orbit.
persistent.action: Three requirements: 24-hour period, above equator, rotating with Earth. All three are needed.

d2.tooltip: What type of force causes circular motion?

d4.tooltip: What type of acceleration changes direction in circular motion?

sentences.text: The velocity of an orbiting satellite is always {{d5}} to the gravitational force, meaning velocity is {{d6}} to the circular path.

d5.tooltip: In uniform circular motion, what angle is between velocity and centripetal force?

d6.tooltip: Velocity shows the instantaneous direction of motion along the path.

centripetal_motion.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of centripetal motion for satellites.

d2.tooltip: Satellites maintain orbit without using fuel for propulsion.

d3.tooltip: Can there be normal force without contact?

d4.tooltip: Satellites orbit in the vacuum of space.

d5.tooltip: The word 'normal' in physics means perpendicular.

d6.tooltip: When standing still, what is the net vertical force?

weightlessness.title: Apparent Weightlessness in Orbit
weightlessness.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of apparent weightlessness.

sentences.text: Astronauts feel weightless in orbit because they are in {{d1}}. In this state, the {{d2}} force is zero.

d1.tooltip: What is the state when gravity is the only force acting?

d2.tooltip: Which force do we actually feel that gives us a sense of weight?

sentences.text: At the altitude of the ISS (400 km), the gravitational field strength is approximately {{d3}} of its surface value. Gravity {{d4}} still acting on the astronauts.

d3.tooltip: Use the inverse square law: at r = 1.06 RE, g is still about 0.9 times surface value.

d4.tooltip: What keeps the ISS in orbit?

d6.tooltip: If astronaut and station fall together, what happens between them?

forces_on_satellites.title: Applying Force Concepts to Satellites
forces_on_satellites.instructions: Apply your understanding of forces to satellite scenarios.

sentences.text: When drawing a free body diagram for an orbiting satellite, you should show {{d1}} force(s). This force points {{d2}} the planet.

d1.tooltip: What forces act on an object in the vacuum of space?

sentences.text: A common misconception is that satellites need engines to stay in orbit. In reality, once in a stable orbit, the satellite {{d3}} to move without propulsion because {{d4}} continuously provides centripetal force.

d3.tooltip: What did Newton's first law say about objects in motion?

d4.tooltip: What non-contact force acts between masses?

sentences.text: If a satellite were moving too slowly for its altitude, it would {{d5}} toward Earth. If moving too fast, it would {{d6}} to a higher orbit or escape.

d5.tooltip: What happens when centripetal force exceeds the required force for that speed?

d6.tooltip: What happens when the object has too much kinetic energy for its orbit?

centripetal_motion.title: Applying Centripetal Motion Concepts
centripetal_motion.instructions: Apply centripetal motion concepts to orbital scenarios.

sentences.text: The Moon orbits Earth at the same rate regardless of its mass because in the equation mv²/r = GMm/r², the {{d1}} cancels, leaving orbital speed dependent only on {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Which quantity appears on both sides of the equation?

d2.tooltip: After cancellation, v = √(GM/r) depends on what?

sentences.text: To calculate orbital radius, you must add the {{d3}} to the altitude above the surface. For the ISS at 400 km altitude, r = 6400 km + 400 km = {{d4}} km.

d3.tooltip: Orbital formulas measure distance from the planet's centre.

sentences.text: In uniform circular motion, the satellite's {{d5}} remains constant while its {{d6}} continuously changes direction.

d5.tooltip: Which scalar quantity stays the same in uniform circular motion?

d6.tooltip: This vector quantity includes both magnitude and direction.

normal_force.title: Applying Normal Force Concepts
normal_force.instructions: Apply normal force concepts to various scenarios.

sentences.text: A person standing on a scale in a stationary elevator reads {{d1}} because the normal force {{d2}} the gravitational force.

d1.tooltip: When at rest on a horizontal surface, how do forces compare?

d2.tooltip: Net force is zero when stationary.

sentences.text: In an elevator accelerating upward, the scale reading {{d3}} because the normal force must provide {{d4}} to accelerate you upward.

d3.tooltip: To accelerate you upward, what must the net force direction be?

d4.tooltip: Net force direction equals acceleration direction.

sentences.text: The key difference between standing on Earth and orbiting in the ISS is the presence of a {{d5}}. On Earth, the floor provides {{d6}}, while in orbit there is no floor.

d5.tooltip: What physical requirement is needed for normal force?

d6.tooltip: What force does the floor exert on you?

weightlessness.title: Applying Weightlessness Concepts
weightlessness.instructions: Apply your understanding of apparent weightlessness to various scenarios.

sentences.text: A person in a falling elevator would feel {{d1}} because they are in {{d2}} along with the elevator.

d1.tooltip: When you and the floor fall together, what happens to normal force?

d2.tooltip: What state occurs when gravity is the only force?

sentences.text: Astronaut training includes flights in aircraft that follow {{d3}} trajectories, creating about 25 seconds of {{d4}} during each parabola.

d3.tooltip: What path does a freely falling projectile follow?

d4.tooltip: When aircraft and passengers are in free fall together, what do passengers experience?

sentences.text: The phrase 'zero gravity' is technically {{d5}} because gravity {{d6}} at orbital altitudes. 'Microgravity' or 'apparent weightlessness' are more accurate terms.

d5.tooltip: Is there actually zero gravitational force in orbit?

d6.tooltip: At 400 km altitude, g is about 8.7 m/s².

forces_on_satellites.title: Mastering Force Concepts in Orbit
forces_on_satellites.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of forces on satellites.

sentences.text: Newton's cannonball thought experiment shows that if a projectile is launched horizontally fast enough, it will {{d1}} the Earth rather than hitting it, because the Earth's surface {{d2}} away at the same rate.

d1.tooltip: Orbital motion is perpetual falling while moving sideways.

d2.tooltip: Earth is spherical, so its surface drops away from a straight line.

sentences.text: The misconception that 'centrifugal force balances gravity' fails because centrifugal force is {{d3}}. From an inertial reference frame, only {{d4}} acts on the satellite.

d3.tooltip: Centrifugal force only appears in rotating reference frames.

d4.tooltip: In the reference frame of someone watching from Earth's surface, what force acts on the satellite?

sentences.text: A satellite's orbital motion demonstrates that an object can accelerate while maintaining constant {{d5}}, because acceleration only requires a change in {{d6}}, which includes direction.

d5.tooltip: In uniform circular motion, what magnitude stays constant?

d6.tooltip: Acceleration is the rate of change of this vector quantity.

centripetal_motion.title: Mastering Centripetal Motion in Orbit
centripetal_motion.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of centripetal motion for satellites.

sentences.text: For a geostationary satellite, the orbital period must equal {{d1}}, the orbit must be above the {{d2}}, and the satellite must orbit in the same direction as Earth's rotation.

d1.tooltip: How long does Earth take to complete one rotation?

d2.tooltip: Where must the orbit be centred to stay above one point?

sentences.text: The fact that a bowling ball and a feather would orbit Earth at the same speed (if at the same altitude) demonstrates that orbital motion is independent of {{d3}}, similar to Galileo's observation about {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Which mass cancels in the orbital motion derivation?

d4.tooltip: Galileo showed all objects fall at the same rate regardless of what property?

sentences.text: Moving a satellite to a higher orbit requires adding energy, which results in a {{d5}} orbital speed and a {{d6}} orbital period.

d5.tooltip: From v = √(GM/r), how does v change when r increases?

d6.tooltip: Larger orbit at lower speed means each lap takes how long?

normal_force.title: Mastering Normal Force Concepts
normal_force.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of normal force in various contexts.

sentences.text: Apparent weight equals the {{d1}} acting on a person. We sense weight not from gravity directly, but from the {{d2}} that surfaces exert on us.

d1.tooltip: What force do bathroom scales actually measure?

d2.tooltip: We feel pressure on our feet, not a force distributed through our body.

d5.tooltip: What is present on Earth's surface but absent in orbit?

weightlessness.title: Mastering Apparent Weightlessness
weightlessness.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of apparent weightlessness.

sentences.text: The term 'microgravity' is preferred over 'zero gravity' because the ISS experiences about {{d1}} of Earth's surface gravity, which is far from {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: The term 'zero gravity' implies what value?

sentences.text: Both an astronaut in the ISS and a skydiver before opening their parachute are in {{d3}}. The key difference is the duration: seconds for the skydiver, but {{d4}} for the astronaut.

d3.tooltip: What state occurs when gravity is the only significant force?

d4.tooltip: How long can orbital free fall last?

sentences.text: The physics of weightlessness reveals that what we perceive as 'weight' is actually our {{d5}} to the surface, not the gravitational force itself. This explains why orbiting astronauts feel weightless despite gravity {{d6}} on them.

d5.tooltip: What creates the sensation we interpret as weight?
